page.title: 02ASHURST BEACON
page.content: Perhaps the most famous landmark of Skelmersdale is the{Beacon}on top of Ashurst Hill. It stands 173m above sea level to the NE of the town. One of the chain of Lancashire beacons which stretched from Everton, Liverpool to Lancaster Castle, it was built in the 16th Century by Sir William Ashurst to serve as an early warning system against invaders. Now it commands a magnificent{view point over many counties. From the foot of the monument visitors can, on a clear day see the mountains of Snowdonia, the Cheshire Plain, the Pennines, Blackpool Tower, the Lake District Mountains and the splendid panorama of Liverpool and the Mersey. Each Good Friday,an{Ecumenical Passion Service is held at the Beacon, when scenes of the Crucifixion are re-enacted by local Christians.
